document_title: Heart valve disease: Causes, symptoms and treatments
subsection_content:
Valvular heart disease is a condition that can be present at birth (congenital) or occur in adulthood for a variety of reasons, such as infections and other cardiovascular diseases.
The heart valves (including the mitral valve, tricuspid valve, pulmonary valve and aortic valve) are located at the exit of the 4 heart chambers, and are responsible for maintaining one-way blood flow through the heart. The four heart valves ensure that blood always flows freely in the forward direction and does not leak in the reverse direction. (first)
Each heart valve has flaps (leaflets) that open and close once during each heartbeat. If one or more valves do not open/close properly, blood flow through the heart to the body will be interrupted, causing valvular heart disease.
